Mark Xu wrote:

> should it be the same as the packge for the source
> codes been tested or not?
> 
> my colleagues argued that it makes it easy to test
> the protected methods or packge scope methods if
> they live in the same package.

Yes, it does. Question: why test protected methods? Further question: 
why make the method protected in the first place?

Testing non-public parts of an interface creates unnecessary coupling 
between tests and production code, hindering refactoring. If you care 
about having the freedom to refactor, then don't test non-public 
methods. If you want to test a non-public method, then maybe it 
shouldn't be public.

Search the archives of this group for more detailed arguments.
